title: 110_hr1216
content: The Act titled "Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act of 2007" or "K.T. Safety Act of 2007" mandates the consideration of rulemaking for power windows on motor vehicles to automatically reverse direction when detecting an obstruction to enhance child safety. The Act mandates motor vehicles to automatically reverse direction when power windows detect an obstruction to prevent injuries or fatalities. The Secretary must decide on safety standards within 30 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must report to Congress if no additional safety standards are deemed reasonable, practicable, and appropriate within 30 months of the Act's enactment. Information on vehicle safety will be made public through various means. The Secretary will provide information on vehicle safety through various means, including the Internet and brochures. A rulemaking will be initiated to expand rearward visibility to reduce accidents caused by backing incidents. The Secretary may prescribe requirements for motor vehicles to improve rearward visibility and reduce accidents involving small children and disabled persons by using additional mirrors, sensors, cameras, or other technology. The Secretary will establish safety standards for motor vehicles to enhance rearward visibility using mirrors, sensors, or cameras. Compliance with the standards must be achieved within 48 months of the final rule issuance. The Secretary will establish safety standards for motor vehicles to enhance rearward visibility, with full compliance required within 48 months of the final rule issuance. The phase-in priorities for the standards will be based on data showing the frequency of backing incidents involving different types of motor vehicles. If any type of vehicle is prioritized, specific regulations will be issued. The Secretary will issue regulations prioritizing certain motor vehicles for rearward visibility safety standards. Motor vehicles with automatic transmission after September 1, 2010, must have a system requiring the brake to be depressed before shifting to park. After September 1, 2010, all vehicles with automatic transmission must have a system that requires the brake to be depressed before shifting out of "park". Violating this requirement is treated as a violation of a motor vehicle safety standard and is subject to enforcement by the Secretary. Each motor vehicle manufacturer must submit information on noncompliant vehicles with automatic transmissions to the Secretary. The make and model of these vehicles must be transmitted annually. The Secretary will publish this information within 30 days of receiving it. The Secretary must publish information on noncompliant motor vehicles with automatic transmissions within 30 days of receiving it, including the make and model. Vehicles not included in the publication are presumed to comply with requirements. The term "motor vehicle" in this Act refers to vehicles under 10,000 pounds gross vehicular weight, excluding motorcycles, trailers, and heavier vehicles. The Secretary will establish a database of injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles rated over 10,000 pounds gross vehicular weight. The database will include information on the number, types, and causes of injuries and deaths, as well as the make, model, and model year of the vehicles. The Secretary will establish a database of injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles over 10,000 pounds. Information on injuries, deaths, vehicle make, model, and year will be included. The database will be made available to the public online. The Secretary will implement a child safety information program within 9 months of the Act's enactment. This program will address hazards to children in nontraffic, noncrash incidents by either enhancing an existing consumer program or creating a new one. The Secretary will use collected data to prioritize safety measures. The Secretary will establish priorities for a child safety program addressing nontraffic, noncrash injuries, and other risks. Information will be made available to the public through various means. If deadlines cannot be met, new ones will be set. The Secretary will establish new deadlines if the ones specified in the Act cannot be met, notifying relevant committees of the reasons for the delay.
